text: hey everyone this is my latest project
this is an individual cookie maker so
this thing has a rotating platform here
and there's going to be stations along
the platform that contain the
ingredients to make a cookie and what
will happen is this thing will rotate
into position and dispense the
ingredients onto a balance and then
rotate to the next position and dispense
this ingredient into the balance and the
balance will be able to measure out very
very small quantities so this is able to
mix a single cookie the benefit of this
is that if each cookie on the sheet can
have a slightly different recipe so that
you could you know eat all of them if
you want or sample all of them and then
figure out how you want to change the
recipe in order to make a cookie that
you like more if we were to expand this
to sort of a business idea of the
factory could make individual cookies
and then put like a QR code on the
cookie wrapper so then the the buyer
could stay on the QR code and just enter
a number of you know one to five how
much I like this cookie and then the
factory can update the recipe even day
by day or hour by hour if they wanted
another cool idea is the factory could
send different recipes to different
regions so for example if all of the
cookies sent to the west coast you know
people rated the sweeter cookies more
highly there than the factory could send
sweeter cookies to the west coast or
whatever it turns out to be so this
project is going to involve a lot of
interesting fluid and powder handling
stuff I'm going to dispense the powdered
ingredients by putting a lead screw into
the funnel and then driving the lead
screw kind of like a drill bit which
will cause the powder to be very very
slowly metered out down the funnel for
the liquid and semi liquid ingredients
I'm going to use syringes for the true
liquids this will be eggs and vanilla
extract and then I'm going to use this
device for the butter so in this video
I'm going to talk about the butter
dispenser so let's take a look at this I
bought this linear actuator assembly off
of ebay and modded it quite a bit to
hold
a metal syringe which is currently
filled with butter and when you activate
the linear actuator the plunger is
pushed down and butter is dispensed out
the bottom so let me tell you about the
process that I use to figure out how to
size the motor and figuring out how this
all is going to work I started by
loading the syringe up with slightly
warm butter I used probably about 70 to
75 degrees F and since I took it out of
the refrigerator I knew it was gonna be
way too viscous straight out of the
refrigerator so I warmed it up a bit and
then put that in the syringe and pushed
down on a an electronic bathroom scale
it's actually a shipping scale to get an
idea of how much force it would take to
push the butter out the nozzle and it
came out to about 8 kilograms force the
nozzle here is responsible for a lot of
the restriction in the butter coming out
so if if it turns out that eight
kilograms force is just a little too
much for this I can go to a larger
nozzle the downside is that a fatter
stream of butter doesn't break up as
easily so if you're just pushing out
like a really fat stream of butter it's
very hard to meet her because the whole
chunk comes out kind of in one blast
this fine nozzle actually helps quite a
bit because the butter breaks up into
droplets not really droplets with sort
of chunks small chunks and those fall
down into the mixing vessel to be bet to
be you know checked on the balance the
next thing I wanted to measure was how
how far this plunger would have to move
down in order to dispense a nominal
cookies value of butter so to start last
weekend I figured out what the values
were for a single cookie and it comes
out to about 4.7 grams of butter per
cookie so I set up my milligram balance
and then just dispense some by hand
measuring how much the plunger moved so
I checked it first dispensed 4.7 grams
or as close as I could get to it and
then checked it again and it turns out
that this plunger was six millimeters
for each 4.7 gram dose I also found out
that the butter tends to make 200ml
Grahame drops I mean there's sort of
more like strings that are coming out of
this thing but at at that temperature at
about 70 to 75 F just squeezing on this
thing with about eight kilograms of
force will cause 200 milligram chunks to
come out which is which is really good
actually that's that's fine accuracy for
this project so knowing that I wanted to
dispense or I wanted to move this six
millimeters I also arbitrarily picked a
dispensing time of about three seconds
so you figure that you know the carousel
rotates into position and then it takes
three seconds to actually dispense the
butter so I measured the pitch on this
lead screw here and this turns out to be
a quarter twenty even though the rest of
this lead screw is metric I guess they
they couldn't find a metric lead screw
or something so with a 50 thousandths of
an inch pitch that means I need 4.7
revolutions in three seconds there's
another interesting little feature here
this lead screw is set up with a two to
one belt drive reduction so this is
actually the nut and the motor turns
this the lead screw is actually fixed to
the frame so the lead screw doesn't
rotate
but this nut does so the belt drive
gives us a little more torque and a
little less speed which actually turned
out not to be helpful but I'll talk
about that in a minute
originally this lead screw didn't have
this motor connected to it and so I had
to figure out how much torque my motor
was going to need to produce eight
kilograms force here and so I started
browsing around and actually found the
Wikipedia article on this subject to be
pretty good hopefully you can see that
it's it's really kind of super
approximation I mean it's I wouldn't
trust this although it's kind of
interesting to go through the exercise
there's a formula on the Wikipedia page
for torque if you know the force on the
lead screw the diameter of the lead
screw and then there's this friction
angle the friction angle is how much
mechanical loss there is in the system
so if you're turning the thing you know
ideally all of that torque would be
converted into linear
but it doesn't work that way because
there's friction so what I did was I I
tried to drive the lead screw backwards
and essentially just pushing on the nut
and then seeing if the thing would turn
just by putting linear force in if if
that is the case then that means that
these two values are approximately equal
because you can overcome the friction
just by pushing on it so I pretended
that these were pretty much equal and
got the value of 13 degrees from this
other formula anyway I'm not going to go
through this but it comes out with the
dolt reduction to be 500 grams
centimeters so when you look through a
catalog they don't rate these in Newton
meters for some reason they always use
grams centimeters because it's a rounder
number and the speed is a hundred ninety
rpm based on that three second dispense
time so then after going through all
this you know just like any good
engineering project you don't actually
use these numbers you just go to the
junk bin or the catalog and see what's
available to build a prototype so I had
this motor here which actually turned
out to be much too strong so I tested
the torque by just clamping a vise grip
on to it and then turning the motor on
and it was able to lift the vise grip up
90 degrees and then I measured the vise
grip mass and and approximate center of
mass and figured out that it was much
too powerful to mount the syringe I just
got a piece of plastic here and then
measured the the diameter inside the
syringe handle and machines this piece
of plastic to fit this way I can sort of
you know make some small adjustments to
the size of this and then just kind of
all push it on like that and it actually
stays quite quite well connected and I
think when it's mounted like like this
it's not going to want to fall out of
there okay well keep you posted on the
project let me know if you have any
questions see you next time bye
